questions.question: In a PHC, which of the following initial screening tests are used to diagnose diabetes? HbA1c >6.5 Fasting blood sugar >126mg/dl Random blood sugar >200mg/dl 2-hour post glucose load blood sugar
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 2 and 4 Explanation: The initial screening for diabetes in a PHC typically involves fasting blood sugar levels >126 mg/dL and a 2-hour post-glucose load blood sugar. The diagnosis of diabetes can be established using any of the following criteria: Fasting Plasma Glucose (FPG): ≥ 126 mg/dL (2) after an overnight fast. The result should be confirmed by repeating the test. Random Plasma Glucose (RPG) (3): > 200 mg/dL, done only if the patient presents with symptoms of diabetes such as polyuria, polydipsia, ketoacidosis, or unexplained weight loss. Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) (4): A two-hour plasma glucose level ≥ 200 mg/dL after a 75-gram oral glucose challenge. For children, the test uses 1.75 gm/kg body weight. HbA1c >6.5 (Option 1) : HbA1c estimation is not typically used in primary health centers (PHC) in India due to limited resources, and it is usually only available in tertiary centers. Reference: https://www.nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/guidelines/nrhm-guidelines/stg/diabetes-mellitus.pdf

questions.question: A 29-year-old male patient presents with coarse facial features and gradual enlargement of the hands and feet for the past decade. He has been diagnosed with acromegaly based on elevated levels of IGF-1 and growth hormone that did not suppress after a 75 g glucose challenge test. What drug is recommended for treatment?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A- Lanreotide depot formulation The clinical manifestations indicate active acromegaly based on typical physical changes and biochemical confirmation. Lanreotide is a somatostatin analog that has high efficacy in controlling GH and IGF-1 levels, as well as its convenient long duration of action . It is administered as a long-acting depot injection and is considered the first line medical therapy for acromegaly. The medication works by binding to somatostatin receptors on the pituitary tumor, effectively reducing GH secretion and consequently normalizing IGF-1 levels. Management of Acromegaly Surgical Treatment Transsphenoidal surgical resection is the preferred treatment, especially for those with GH-secreting adenomas. Post-Surgery: Improvement in soft tissue swelling and normalization of GH levels typically occur shortly after surgery IGF-1 levels normalize within 3-4 days. There is a 10% recurrence rate of acromegaly years later, and up to 15% of patients may develop hypopituitarism. Medical therapy Preferred in medical therapy if curative surgery is not feasible or if GH fails to decrease post resection Somatostatin Receptor Ligands (SRLs): Long-acting injectable forms (octreotide, lanreotide) . Normalizes GH and IGF-1 levels in about 50% of patients. Side Effects : GI disturbances, transient nausea, and gallbladder issues. GH receptor antagonist: Pegvisomant blocks peripheral GH receptors, normalizing IGF-1 levels in about 70% of patients, though GH levels remain elevated. It is administered through daily subcutaneous injections and is used for recurrences or poor responses to SRLs. Dopamine Agonists: High doses of cabergoline can provide modest GH suppression. Radiation Therapy External beam radiation therapy or stereotactic techniques are considered for patients not achieving biochemical control through surgery or medical therapy. Terlipressin (Option B): Terlipressin is a synthetic vasopressin analog used primarily for the treatment of hepatorenal syndrome and bleeding esophageal varices. It has no role in the treatment of acromegaly as it does not affect GH secretion or action. Ketoconazole (Option C): Ketoconazole is an antifungal medication. While it has been used off-label for some endocrine conditions (such as adrenal hypercortisolism), it is not indicated for acromegaly management as it does not affect GH or IGF-1 levels. Leuprolide (Option D) : Leuprolide is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist commonly used for the treatment of conditions such as prostate cancer and endometriosis. It does not have any effect on GH secretion and is therefore not effective in treating acromegaly. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2912, 2913, 2914

questions.question: A patient presents with complaints of sudden onset headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating. The patient has had multiple similar episodes in the past. During these episodes, the patient's blood pressure is elevated. A 24-hour urine metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Pheochromocytoma The clinical manifestations indicate pheochromocytoma based on the classic triad of symptoms and elevated urinary metanephrines . Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor that produces excessive amounts of catecholamines, leading to paroxysmal symptoms including sudden onset headache, palpitations, and profuse sweating . The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring elevated levels of urinary metanephrines, which is considered the most sensitive diagnostic test for pheochromocytoma. The episodic nature of symptoms along with documented elevation in blood pressure during these episodes strongly supports this diagnosis. Pheochromocytoma Description Pheochromocytomas are rare tumors arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla. The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines. Clinical features Classical triad Episode of palpitation Headache Profuse sweating Dominant sign is Hypertension Tachycardia Anxiety Subcutaneous neurofibromas Cafe-au-lait macules Thyroid mass Axillary freckling Lisch nodules on the iris Retinal angiomas Abdominal mass Diagnosis Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines . 24-hour urine test Catecholamines Fractionated metanephrines Total metanephrines Imaging : CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumor. 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease. MIBG scintigraphy Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning Differential Diagnosis Hyperthyroidism Renal artery stenosis Hyperaldosteronism Cardiomyopathy Postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS) Addison's disease (Option A): Addison's disease is primary adrenocortical failure and presents with symptoms like fatigue, weight loss, low blood pressure, and skin hyperpigmentation. While adrenal crisis can cause symptoms such as headache and sweating, it does not cause an episodic elevation of blood pressure and is characterized by hypotension rather than hypertension. Also elevated metanephrines is not a finding in Addison’s disease. Renal artery stenosis (Option B): Renal artery stenosis can lead to high blood pressure but does not cause sudden onset headaches, palpitation, and profuse sweating. An elevated 24-hour urine metanephrine is not associated with renal artery stenosis as this condition affects the renovascular system rather than catecholamine production. Hyperthyroidism (Option D): Hyperthyroidism symptoms include weight loss, increased appetite, tremors, heat intolerance, palpitations, and sweating. However, an elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine is not associated with hyperthyroidism, and the symptoms are typically continuous rather than episodic.

questions.question: In a 60-year-old male, what is the primary etiology typically associated with Cushing's disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D- Pituitary microadenoma Cushing's disease in a 60-year-old male is most commonly caused by a pituitary microadenoma . This condition is characterized by a benign ACTH-secreting tumor in the pituitary gland, leading to hypercortisolism through increased ACTH production . The excessive ACTH stimulates the adrenal glands to produce higher levels of cortisol, resulting in the classic features of Cushing's syndrome. Cushing's syndrome- Definition and Causes Definition: Cushing's syndrome is a collection of symptoms resulting from prolonged exposure to high levels of glucocorticoids. Cushing's disease specifically refers to Cushing's syndrome caused by a pituitary corticotrope adenoma. It is relatively rare, but mild cases may be more common, particularly among those with symptoms like central obesity, type 2 diabetes and osteoporosis. Causes: Cushing's syndrome can be caused by various factors, categorised as ACTH-dependent or ACTH-independent. I) ACTH-dependent Cushing's Syndrome accounts for approximately 90% of cases. Cushing's disease (ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma) is the most common cause. Ectopic ACTH syndrome occurs when a non-pituitary tumour secretes ACTH . II) ACTH-independent Cushing's Syndrome constitutes the remaining 10% of cases. Adrenocortical adenoma is the most prevalent cause, accounting for 5–10% of all cases. Rare causes include: Primary bilateral macronodular adrenal hyperplasia (PBMAH) Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease (PPNAD) McCune-Albright syndrome Small-cell lung cancer (Option A) can produce ACTH or ACTH-like substances, resulting in paraneoplastic Cushing's syndrome. However, it is not the most common cause of Cushing's disease in an elderly patient. Small-cell lung cancer typically presents with additional respiratory symptoms and a more rapid onset of hypercortisolism features. Adrenal tumor (Option B) can cause Cushing's syndrome through autonomous cortisol production by either an adenoma or carcinoma. However, these tumors bypass the pituitary-adrenal axis and typically suppress ACTH levels, unlike the elevated ACTH seen in Cushing's disease caused by a pituitary microadenoma. Ectopic ACTH syndrome (Option C) occurs when non-pituitary tumors (such as lung, pancreas, or thymus) produce ACTH. While this is a recognized cause of Cushing's syndrome, it is less common than pituitary microadenomas as the primary cause of Cushing's disease in older adults. Ectopic ACTH syndrome typically presents with more rapid onset and severe metabolic derangements.

questions.question: A 30-year-old female patient presented with bone pain and abdominal cramps. Her family reported a previous history of abnormal behavior. The consultant doctor made a tentative diagnosis based on the clinical symptoms. What would be the most appropriate investigative method to establish a conclusive diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C- Sestamibi scan The clinical presentation suggests primary hyperparathyroidism , characterized by the triad of bone pain (from increased bone resorption), abdominal cramps (from hypercalcemia), and neuropsychiatric symptoms (manifesting as abnormal behavior) . Sestamibi scan is the preferred imaging modality for localizing parathyroid adenomas , which are the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism. Primary Hyperparathyroidism- Lab and Radiological findings Lab Investigations Serum calcium levels Increased Serum phosphate levels Decreased Serum alkaline phosphatase (SAP) levels Increased Serum PTH (parathyroid hormone) assay Elevated PTH Radiological features Features Image Subperiosteal erosions and terminal resorption in the phalanges (usually starts in the middle phalanx of the index finger's radial side ) along with bone demineralisation. The "salt and pepper" appearance, or pepper pot skull (lytic lesions in the skull). Brown tumour or osteitis fibrosa cystica: Cystic lesions in bone from excessive osteoclastic resorption appear as low-density, multiloculated cysts that can lead to bone expansion, accompanied by bleeding and granulation tissue. Sestamibi scan (Tc-99): Localize the parathyroid adenoma. MRI (Option A) while capable of identifying soft tissue masses, is not the first-line imaging modality for parathyroid adenoma detection. MRI is more expensive, time-consuming, and does not offer any significant advantage over sestamibi scanning for parathyroid imaging. Ultrasonogram (Option B) can identify parathyroid masses but has limitations in detecting ectopic parathyroid tissue and is highly operator-dependent. It may be used as a complementary imaging technique but is not the most sensitive primary diagnostic tool. CT scan (Option D) provides detailed anatomical imaging but lacks the functional information provided by sestamibi scanning. While CT may be useful for surgical planning, it is not the initial imaging modality of choice for diagnosing parathyroid adenomas.

questions.question: Which medication is recommended as the primary treatment for high blood sugar in a 19-year-old woman with a medical history of type 1 diabetes mellitus, who has been brought to the emergency room due to symptoms of confusion, vomiting, and abdominal pain, and subsequently diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis?
questions.explanation: and correct the acid-base and electrolyte imbalances. Regular insulin is the drug of choice for the management of hyperglycemia in DKA. It is a fast-acting insulin that is given intravenously and has a rapid onset of action, which helps to lower the blood glucose level quickly. Incorrect choices: Option b: Lente insulin is a combination of short-acting and long-acting insulin, which is used for the management of type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus. It has a delayed onset of action and is not effective for the rapid correction of hyperglycemia in DKA. Option c: 70/30 insulin is a combination of intermediate-acting and short-acting insulin, which is used for the management of type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus. It is not appropriate for the rapid correction of hyperglycemia in DKA. Option d: Glyburide is an oral hypoglycemic agent that is used for the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus. It works by stimulating the release of insulin from the pancreas. It is not appropriate for the management of DKA as it does not lower the blood glucose level quickly enough to be effective in the treatment of this condition.

questions.question: Which of the following is seen in MEN 2B syndrome?
questions.explanation: that arises from the C cells of the thyroid gland. Explanation: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) is a group of genetic syndromes (Autosomal Dominant) characterized by the development of tumors in multiple endocrine glands. Diagnostic criteria for MEN is Clinical features of 2 or more associated tumors Notable Family history Confirmation by genetic analysis. Types of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia MEN Type I (Wermer’s syndrome) MEN Type II (Sipple’s syndrome) MEN Type III (MEN II B) MEN Type IV Cause Defect of chr.11q13 causing MEN 1 gene mutation Defect of chr.10 leading to mutation of RET gene Variant of Type 2 MEN Defect of chr.12 causing CDKN1B gene Tumors Included Parathyroid adenoma (m/c) Enteropancreatic adenoma Pituitary adenoma Medullary thyroid carcinoma (m/c) Pheochromocytoma Parathyroid adenoma (Option C) (Calcium can be normal) Medullary thyroid carcinoma (m/c) Pheochromocytoma (high blood pressure) Parathyroid adenoma (Presents as hypercalcemia) Pituitary adenoma Reproductive tract tumors Testicular tumors Neuroendocrine tumor (Cervix) Associated conditions Angio I broma Collagenoma Adrenocortical tumor Carcinoid tumors/ Argenta I noma Pheochromocytoma (only in 1%) Bronchopulmonary NET Thymic NET Gastric NET Lipomas Meningiomas Congenital aganglionosis, Hirschsprung disease Marfanoid habitus Medullated corneal nerve I bers Mucosal neuromas Megacolon and Multiple diverticulae Renal tumor Adrenal tumor Café au lait spots (Option A) are light brown patches on the skin and are commonly seen in conditions such as neurofibromatosis. Optic nerve gliomas (Option D) are not typically associated with MEN 2B syndrome. They are more commonly seen in neurofibromatosis type 1. Reference: Harrison’s principle of internal medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2983 - 2990 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 868, 869

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Kallmann syndrome?
questions.explanation: and is associated with anosmia or hyposmia due to olfactory bulb agenesis or hypoplasia. Kallmann Syndrome: Pathophysiology: Kallmann syndrome results from defective synthesis of hypothalamic gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH). It is often accompanied by anosmia or hyposmia due to agenesis or hypoplasia of the olfactory bulb. This defect occurs due to mutations that impair the embryonic migration of GnRH neurons from the olfactory placode to the hypothalamus. Associated Features: Neurological and Physical Abnormalities: Anosmia or hyposmia Color blindness Optic atrophy Nerve deafness Cleft palate Cryptorchidism Renal abnormalities Mirror movements (neurological) Genetic Basis: Initial discovery: X-linked KAL gene mutations. Other genetic mutations include autosomal recessive (e.g., GPR54, KISS1) and dominant (e.g., FGFR1) mutations. Additional genes: GNRH1, PROK2, PROKR2, CHD7, PCSK1, FGF8, NELF, WDR11, TAC3, TACR3, SEMA3E. Some cases involve oligogenic mutations where multiple gene mutations contribute to the phenotype. Clinical Presentation: Males: Delayed puberty, hypogonadal features (e.g., micropenis, due to low testosterone during infancy). Females: Primary amenorrhea and lack of secondary sexual development. Low levels of luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and sex steroids (testosterone or estradiol). Diagnosis: Typically, it is a diagnosis of exclusion after ruling out other causes of hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction. Repetitive GnRH administration restores pituitary gonadotropin responses, indicating a hypothalamic defect. Treatment: Males: Long-term human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) or testosterone therapy to induce pubertal development and secondary sex characteristics. Females: Cyclic estrogen and progestin therapy to induce secondary sexual development. Fertility Restoration: Administration of gonadotropins or pulsatile GnRH delivery via a portable infusion pump. Syndactyly in males (Option B): Associated with Apert or Poland syndromes, not Kallmann syndrome. Precocious puberty in females (Option C): Kallmann syndrome causes delayed puberty, not precocious puberty, due to deficient GnRH secretion. White forelock (Option D): A white forelock (poliosis) is a feature of Waardenburg syndrome, a genetic disorder associated with sensorineural hearing loss, pigmentary abnormalities, and dystopia canthorum but not Kallmann syndrome. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 2896, 2897

questions.question: What would be the most suitable course of action for managing a 65-year-old male who presented with symptoms of weakness, lethargy, excessive cold intolerance, and slow ankle jerk? His thyroid function test (TFT) revealed a TSH level of 16 Mu/L (normal range: 0.4 - 4.0 mu / l), T4 level of 0.3 ng/dl (normal range: 0.6 - 1.6 ng / dl), and T3 level of 70 pg /dl.

options.A: Start levothyroxine at 100 micrograms and decrease the dose gradually
options.B: Start levothyroxine at 25 micrograms and increase the dose gradually
options.C: Start levothyroxine at 25 micrograms and decrease the dose gradually
options.D: Give T3 and T4 drugs simultaneously

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Start levothyroxine at 25 micrograms and increase the dose gradually hypothyroidism . The most appropriate management for primary hypothyroidism is to initiate treatment with levothyroxine , a synthetic form of thyroid hormone. The initial dose of levothyroxine should be low and gradually increased until the patient reaches the optimal replacement dose. Starting with a dose of 25 micrograms is a common practice in such cases. Clinical Features of Hypothyroidism: Fatigue, weakness and increased sleep Cold intolerance, Weight gain Dry, coarse skin, Hair loss Constipation Depression and cognitive impairment Menstrual irregularities and infertility Bradycardia Myxedema Hoarse voice Carpal tunnel syndrome, Slow reflexes Goiter, Anemia, Hypercholesterolemia Thyroid Function Test : TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone) Normal range: 0.4-4.0 mIU/L Interpretation of Results: Condition TSH Free T4 Free T3 Primary hypothyroidism ↑ ↓ ↓ Primary hyperthyroidism ↓ (<0.1 mIU/L) ↑ ↑ Subclinical hypothyroidism ↑ Normal Normal Subclinical hyperthyroidism ↓ Normal Normal Secondary hypothyroidism ↓ or Approximately normal ↓ ↓ T3 thyrotoxicosis ↓ Normal ↑ Treatment of hypothyroidism: Levothyroxine - 1.6 µg/kg to be started Available as 25 µg / 50 µg / 88 µg / 100 µg If the dose is >100µg, it increases O2 consumption resulting in angina. Hence, careful titration of dose increments should be done. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 2931- 2935

questions.question: Fulminant diabetes mellitus is seen in?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Coxsackie B virus Explanation: Fulminant diabetes mellitus is associated with coxsackie B virus infection . Fulminant Diabetes: A rapidly progressing subtype of type 1 diabetes, leading to severe hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis within a short time. Pathogenesis: Exact cause unclear but likely involves genetic factors (HLA genes, especially DR4-DQ4) and viral infections ( coxsackieviruses A4, A5, A6, B1 , rotavirus, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, human herpes virus (HHV)-6, and HHV-7) Clinical Features: Rapid onset: Average duration of hyperglycemic symptoms is 4 days. Preceding symptoms: Common-cold-like symptoms and gastrointestinal symptoms are frequent. Near-normal glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c): Despite severe hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis. Absent C-peptide levels: Indicating no residual insulin secretion. No autoantibodies against pancreatic β -cells: Unlike classic type 1 diabetes. Elevated pancreatic enzyme levels. Possible association with pregnancy. Diagnosis: Based on rapid progression of hyperglycemia, ketoacidosis, and the above clinical features. Treatment: Immediate management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) with: Intravenous saline infusion. Regular insulin therapy. Long-term insulin therapy: Continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion (CSII) or multiple daily injections (MDI). Prognosis: Without immediate treatment, death can occur within 24 hours. Early recognition and prompt intervention are critical for survival. Diabetic ketoacidosis (Option A) (DKA) is a serious complication of diabetes, characterized by hyperglycemia, ketone production, and metabolic acidosis. However, it is a consequence rather than a cause of fulminant diabetes. Non-ketotic hyperosmolar coma (Option C) is a life-threatening complication of diabetes, marked by extremely high blood sugar and severe dehydration. Unlike fulminant diabetes, it is typically seen in type 2 diabetes. Autoimmune pancreatitis (Option D) is a rare form of chronic pancreatitis caused by an autoimmune reaction. While it can lead to endocrine dysfunction, it does not cause the rapid and severe destruction of β -cells seen in fulminant type 1 diabetes. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 3095 https://academic.oup.com/jcem/article/108/12/e1473/7194776 https://www.nature.com/articles/ncpendmet0351

questions.question: A comatose elderly patient with a weight of approximately 70 kilograms is presented to the emergency department. During examination, it was determined that the patient's serum glucose levels were 500mg/dL, arterial pH is 7.30, and there is an elevation in plasma ketones levels. However, the serum potassium levels are within the normal range. In order to treat this patient, which of the following should be added to the saline solution?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Insulin Explanation: The patient's clinical features suggest diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a potentially life-threatening complication of uncontrolled diabetes. Insulin is the mainstay of treatment in DKA as it helps lower blood glucose levels and suppresses ketone production. DKA is characterized by hyperglycemia, metabolic acidosis, and the presence of ketones in the blood. To manage DKA, it is crucial to address the underlying cause of hyperglycemia and correct metabolic derangements. Updated Management of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (ISPAD 2022): Contraindication of Insulin Drip: Insulin should be withheld if the serum potassium level is below 3.3 mmol/L. The target is to maintain serum potassium levels above 3.5 mmol/L (3.5 meq/L) to start the insulin drip. Hypokalemia can lead to diaphragmatic paralysis and potentially result in respiratory arrest. Bicarbonate (Option B) administration is generally not recommended for DKA unless the patient has severe acidosis (arterial pH <7.0). In this case, the arterial pH of 7.33 does not indicate severe acidosis, and thus, bicarbonate is not necessary. Potassium (Option C) levels are normal in this patient, so additional potassium supplementation may not be required. However, regular monitoring of potassium levels is essential during the treatment of DKA, as insulin administration can cause a shift of potassium into the cells, leading to potential hypokalemia. If the patient's potassium levels decrease during treatment, appropriate potassium supplementation can be initiated. The specific dose of 14 units of regular insulin intravenously (Option D) is not mentioned in the initial description and cannot be determined solely based on the given information. The insulin dosage should be individualized based on the patient's clinical condition, blood glucose levels, and response to treatment. It is typically administered as an initial bolus followed by continuous intravenous infusion.

questions.question: Addison's disease is characterized by all of the following symptoms except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Hyperglycemia Explanation: Individuals with Addison's disease may experience hypoglycemia (Not Hyperglycemia) (low blood sugar) due to the inadequate production of cortisol, a hormone involved in regulating blood sugar levels. Addison's disease refers to primary adrenocortical failure . Etiology Autoimmune: M/C/C Worldwide Sporadic Polyglandular syndromes Tuberculosis: M/C/C in India Histoplasmosis HIV/AIDS Metastatic carcinoma Bilateral adrenalectomy Clinical features Glucocorticoid insufficiency: Weight loss, anorexia, malaise, weakness, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or constipation, postural hypotension, shock, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia (Option B) (dilutional), hypercalcemia Mineralocorticoid insufficiency: Hypotension (Option D) , shock, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia (Option C) ACTH excess: Pigmentation Adrenal androgen insufficiency: Decreased body hair and loss of libido, especially in females Reference: Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th edition, pages 671-672

questions.question: What is the preferred medication for treating Hyperthyroidism during the second trimester of pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Carbimazole Explanation: Carbimazole is the preferred medication for treating hyperthyroidism during the second trimester of pregnancy . Carbimazole is a thyroid peroxidase inhibitor that has higher potency and longer half life than propylthiouracil. However, it crosses the placenta easily, and can cause aplasia cutis in the fetus. For this reason, Carbimazole is not administered during the 1st trimester. Management of Hyperthyroidism in Pregnancy Medical Management First Trimester: Propylthiouracil 100-300mg/day (three times daily) Mechanism: Inhibits hormone synthesis + Thyroxine to Triiodothyronine conversion Second/Third Trimester: Methimazole 5-15mg/day (once daily) Monitoring: Thyroid Function Tests every 2-4 weeks Thyroid Stimulating Hormone Receptor Antibodies: 18-22 weeks, 30-34 weeks Target: Free Thyroxine upper normal, Thyroid Stimulating Hormone slightly low Thyroid Storm Protocol Propanolol Potassium Iodide/Lugol's solution (60 minutes post-antithyroid drugs) Propylthiouracil/Methimazole administration Glucocorticoids Intensive care support Mortality: 20-30% if untreated Teratogenicity Methimazole Embryopathy: Aplasia cutis Choanal/esophageal atresia Dysmorphic facies PTU Associated: Isolated anomalies Situs inversus Renal tract malformations Contraindications Radioactive iodine First trimester thyroidectomy Fetal Surveillance Ultrasound markers: Thyroid dimensions Fetal heart rate (>160/min significant) Growth parameters Hydrops features Bone maturation Propyl Thiouracil (Option A) : While propylthiouracil is the drug of choice during the first trimester of pregnancy due to lower risk of birth defects, it is not the preferred option during the second trimester. The switch to carbimazole is recommended after the first trimester due to its better efficacy and safety profile. Sodium iodide (Option C) : This medication is contraindicated during pregnancy as it can cross the placenta and affect fetal thyroid function. It can cause fetal hypothyroidism and goiter formation. Radioactive iodine (Option D) : Radioactive iodine is absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy as it readily crosses the placenta and can affect the fetal thyroid gland, potentially causing miscarriage or serious developmental issues. It should never be used during any stage of pregnancy. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page 2938.

questions.question: A 30-year-old female patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of neck swelling. She gives a history of weight loss and palpitations. On examination, she has exophthalmos and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. What are the essential investigations that should be done for the patient? Thyroid scan Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) Thyroid function tests Ultrasound of neck Anti-thyroid antibody
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1,3,4 and 5 only Explanation: The clinical scenario of a female with neck swelling, weight loss, palpitations, exophthalmos, and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland suggests a diagnosis of Grave’s disease. The essential investigations for this patient include thyroid function tests (TFT), ultrasound of the neck, thyroid scan, and anti-thyroid antibodies . Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is not essential in this case. Grave’s Disease: Onset typically between 20-50 years ; rare before adolescence but occurs in the elderly. Pathogenesis: Combination of genetics (e.g., HLA-DR, CTLA-4) and environmental factors (e.g., stress, iodine intake). Associated with thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSIs), which activate the TSH receptor. Clinical Manifestations: Weight loss (despite increased appetite), or rarely, weight gain. Hyperactivity, nervousness, fatigue, tremors, heat intolerance, sweating. Cardiovascular: Sinus tachycardia, atrial fibrillation (in older patients), palpitation. Neurological: Hyperreflexia, muscle weakness, rare chorea. Skin: Warm, moist skin; palmar erythema, alopecia, hyperpigmentation. GI: Increased stool frequency, diarrhea. Bone: Osteopenia, mild hypercalcemia. Specific to Grave’s disease: Diffuse thyroid enlargement (thrill/bruit may be present). Ophthalmopathy : Proptosis, diplopia, and optic neuropathy. Dermopathy (pretibial myxedema): Indurated, pink-purple plaques with "orange-skin" appearance. Acropachy (clubbing), rare. Investigation: TSH and Thyroid Hormones : (3) Grave’s disease shows suppressed TSH levels with elevated total and unbound thyroid hormone levels. T3 toxicosis (elevated T3 with normal T4) occurs in 2-5% of cases or more in areas with borderline iodine intake. T4 toxicosis (elevated T4 with normal T3) can be seen with iodine-induced hyperthyroidism. Antibody Testing : (5) TPO antibodies or TRAb testing is useful for unclear cases but not routinely needed. Associated Abnormalities: Elevated bilirubin, liver enzymes, and ferritin. Microcytic anemia and thrombocytopenia may occur. Radionuclide scan and uptake (1) (e.g., 99mTc, 123I) differentiate Grave’s disease from thyroiditis, ectopic thyroid tissue, factitious thyrotoxicosis, toxic adenoma, or multinodular goiter. Color-Flow Doppler Ultrasonography (4): Differentiates hyperthyroidism (increased blood flow) from destructive thyroiditis. Treatment: Antithyroid drugs: Propylthiouracil (provide symptomatic relief) Radioiodine treatment (I131): Mainly used in elderly patients with surgical comorbidities or recurrence after surgery. Thyroidectomy: Treatment of choice, especially when other methods fail or are contraindicated. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2938-2942

questions.question: A patient presents with hypotension, hyponatremia and blackening of the knuckles and perioral area. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with these symptoms?
questions.explanation: insufficient cortisol production affecting blood pressure. Hyponatremia : Caused by low aldosterone levels, leading to reduced sodium reabsorption. Hyperpigmentation : Characterized by darkening of the skin, including knuckles and perioral areas, due to increased ACTH levels stimulating melanocytes. Incorrect Options: Option A - Conn Syndrome: Characterized by primary hyperaldosteronism, which typically leads to hypertension, hypokalemia (low potassium), and metabolic alkalosis, but not usually associated with hyperpigmentation or hyponatremia. Option B - Cushing’s Syndrome: Results from excess cortisol production and can present with hypertension, hyperglycemia, and hypokalemia. Hyperpigmentation is not a common feature; instead, you might see features such as easy bruising and a “moon facies.” Option C - Primary ACTH Deficiency: Leads to low cortisol levels but not usually associated with hyperpigmentation. Patients may experience symptoms of adrenal insufficiency, but hyperpigmentation is more characteristic of primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison’s disease) rather than ACTH deficiency.

questions.question: During her pregnancy, a woman who had Grave's disease was consistently taking. Consequently, the newborn suffered from aplasia cutis congenita. Which specific medication could be attributed to the occurrence of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Carbimazole Explanation: Carbimazole is the antithyroid medication which can cause aplasia cutis congenita , a rare condition characterized by the scalp formation defect, absence of skin in localized or widespread areas at birth. Hence it is contraindicated in the 1st trimester of pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects on the fetus. Carbimazole Carbimazole is a thyroid peroxidase inhibitor and is the prodrug of methimazole. Uses: DOC in hyperthyroidism and Graves disease. DOC in the second and third trimester of pregnancy. Used alongside I-131 in patients with severe hyperthyroidism to prevent flare-ups from stored T4. The adverse effects include Teratogenic- Cutis aplasia , Esophageal atresia, Choanal atresia. Maculopapular rash Arthralgia Cholestatic jaundice Differences between propylthiouracil and carbimazole: Propylthiouracil Carbimazole (Prodrug of Methimazole) Less potent 5 x more potent Highly plasma protein-bound Less plasma protein bound Less transferred across the placenta and in milk Large amounts transferred across the placenta and in milk Plasma t½ 1-2 hours; Acts for 4-8 hours Plasma t½ 6-10 hours; Acts for 12-24 hours Multiple (2-3) daily doses Single daily dose Inhibits peripheral T4 to T3 conversion Does not inhibit T4 to T3 conversion DOC in the first trimester of pregnancy. (less teratogenic) C/I in 2nd and 3rd trimesters. DOC in 2nd and 3rd trimester of pregnancy. (less hepatotoxic) C/I in the first trimester. Levothyroxine (Option B) is a synthetic thyroid hormone used to treat hypothyroidism. It is not associated with an increased risk of aplasia cutis congenita.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions are most commonly associated with elevated TSH levels and decreased T4 levels?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Hashimoto's thyroiditis Explanation: Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder leading to chronic inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue. This results in decreased production of T3 and T4 hormones. As a compensatory mechanism, the pituitary gland releases more TSH to stimulate the thyroid gland, causing increased TSH levels. Primary vs Secondary Hypothyroidism: Feature Primary Hypothyroidism Secondary Hypothyroidism Definition Thyroid gland dysfunction leads to inadequate thyroid hormone production Pituitary dysfunction leads to insufficient TSH secretion Causes Autoimmune (Hashimoto's thyroiditis) Iatrogenic (e.g., post-thyroidectomy, radiation) Iodine deficiency Medications (e.g., amiodarone, lithium) Infiltrative diseases (e.g., sarcoidosis) Food goitrogen → Cabbage, cassava. Pituitary tumors Pituitary surgery or radiation Sheehan’s syndrome Trauma Genetic pituitary hormone deficiencies Non-obstetric cause of pituitary damage called Simmonds's disease (AVM, tumor, HTN) Sarcoidosis Hemochromatosis Lab TSH - ↑ ; Free T3/T4 - ↓ TSH - Normal or ↓ ; Free T3/T4 - ↓ Clinical Features Fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance Dry skin, hair loss Bradycardia, constipation Myxedema (puffy face, non-pitting edema) Similar to primary hypothyroidism Other pituitary hormone deficiencies (e.g., low cortisol, low LH/FSH) Treatment Levothyroxine (T4) replacement with dosage based on TSH levels Levothyroxine (T4) replacement, but monitored by free T4 levels (since TSH is unreliable) Hypoparathyroidism (Option A) is a condition characterized by inadequate production or secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands. While Pituitary Adenoma (Option B) can cause various hormonal imbalances, such as excessive production of prolactin (leading to hyperprolactinemia), it does not typically result in increased TSH and low T4 levels. In Grave's disease (Option C), TSH levels are typically decreased due to the negative feedback mechanism resulting from high levels of thyroid hormones Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 2933

questions.question: A diabetic patient walks into your clinic and does “namaste”. The image is given below. What could be the probable cause?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cheiroarthropathy Explanation: Cheiroarthropathy is related to long-standing poor glycemic control and the accumulation of advanced glycation end-products (AGEs) in the skin and soft tissues.This can cause difficulty in fully extending the fingers, leading to a characteristic hand posture resembling the "namaste" gesture. While flexor tenosynovitis (Option A) can occur in individuals with diabetes, it does not specifically explain the "namaste" gesture mentioned in the question. Although Dupuytren's contracture (Option C) is associated with certain risk factors, such as family history and alcoholism, it is not directly related to the "namaste" gesture. While ankylosis (Option D) can occur in various conditions, including certain forms of arthritis, trauma, or infection, it does not specifically explain the "namaste" gesture in the context of a diabetic patient.

questions.question: A 12-year-old child who is known to have type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with confusion and drowsiness. Her mother says that she seems to be breathing very fast. On examination, mucous membranes are dry, and blood pressure is 70/50 mmHg. Random blood glucose is 415 mg/d,l and urine ketones are 4+. What is the next best step in management?

options.A: 2-3 L of normal saline over 1-3 hours

questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Arterial blood gas The child’s presentation with confusion, tachypnea (Kussmaul respirations), dry mucous membranes, hypotension, hyperglycemia, and positive urine ketones strongly points to diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) . The next step is an arterial blood gas (ABG) to assess the severity of acidosis and guide management. Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA): Is a hyperglycemic emergency characterized primarily by a triad of hyperglycemia, ketosis, and anion gap metabolic acidosis. Serious complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. Clinical Features: Symptoms Signs Nausea, vomiting Abdominal pain Shortness of breath Thirst, polyuria Weight loss Weakness Leg cramps Blurred vision Tachycardia Dehydration Hypotension (postural or supine) Tachypnea Kussmaul respirations (air hunger) Smell of acetone Respiratory distress Hypothermia Cold extremities/peripheral cyanosis Abdominal tenderness (may resemble acute pancreatitis or surgical abdomen) Lethargy/obtundation/cerebral oedema/possibly coma Investigations of DKA: Urine ketostix: Detects acetoacetate and acetate , but cannot detect ß-hydroxybutyrate. Serum ß-hydroxybutyrate: Produced three times more than acetoacetate and is preferred for accurate diagnosis of DKA. Random Blood Sugar: 250 - 600 mg/dL Serum electrolytes: Potassium: Total body potassium deficiency of 3-6 mEq/kg in DKA occurs due to osmotic diuresis and vomiting. Insulin shifts potassium intracellularly, lowering serum levels, and potassium correction with IV potassium chloride (KCl) should be done. Sodium: Serum sodium is reduced due to hyperglycemia: 1.6 meq/L reduction in sodium per 100 mg/dL rise in serum glucose. Dilutional hyponatremia is common due to water driven into the intravascular space from inside cells. Renal function test: Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis: pH: 6.8-7.3 pCO2: 20-30 mmHg HCO3: <18 meq/L Anion gap: Increased Indicates DKA causes High anion gap metabolic acidosis. Serum amylase and lipase: High Total leukocyte count: Increased Phosphorus and magnesium levels: Reduced, but not accurately shown due to hypovolemia and hyperglycemia. 2-3 L of normal saline over 1-3 hours (Option A): Fluid resuscitation is essential in DKA, but without knowing the acid-base status through an ABG, it is not appropriate to start fluid therapy blindly. The ABG will guide the volume and rate of fluid administration based on the patient’s acidosis and hydration status. Insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour (Option B): Insulin therapy is critical, but it should be initiated after evaluating the patient’s acid-base status through an ABG. Correcting fluid and electrolyte imbalances is essential before starting insulin to avoid complications like hypokalemia and worsening dehydration. Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg (Option D): While insulin is needed, a bolus should not be given without first assessing the acid-base status and correcting fluid and electrolyte imbalances.

questions.question: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain. Investigations revealed low plasma TSH concentration. However, on the administration of TRH, the TSH levels increased. Which of the conditions is likely in this patient?

options.A: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
options.B: Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
options.C: Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus
options.D: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus Explanation: The patient's symptoms of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain point towards hypothyroidism. The increase in TSH levels upon TRH administration indicates a lack of proper stimulus for TSH secretion from the hypothalamus. Feature Primary Hypothyroidism Secondary Hypothyroidism Definition Thyroid gland dysfunction leads to inadequate thyroid hormone production Pituitary dysfunction leads to insufficient TSH secretion Causes Autoimmune (Hashimoto's thyroiditis) Iatrogenic (e.g., post-thyroidectomy, radiation) Iodine deficiency Medications (e.g., amiodarone, lithium) Infiltrative diseases (e.g., sarcoidosis) Food goitrogen → Cabbage, cassava. Pituitary tumors Pituitary surgery or radiation Sheehan’s syndrome Trauma Genetic pituitary hormone deficiencies Non-obstetric cause of pituitary damage called Simmonds's disease (AVM, tumor, HTN) Sarcoidosis Hemochromatosis Lab TSH - ↑ Free T3/T4 - ↓ TSH - Normal or ↓ Free T3/T4 - ↓ Clinical Features Fatigue, weight gain , cold intolerance Dry skin, hair loss Increased sleep Bradycardia, constipation Myxedema (puffy face, non-pitting edema) Similar to primary hypothyroidism Other pituitary hormone deficiencies (e.g., low cortisol, low LH/FSH) Treatment Levothyroxine (T4) replacement with dosage based on TSH levels Levothyroxine (T4) replacement, but monitored by free T4 levels (since TSH is unreliable) Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary (Option A) would result in elevated TSH and thyroid hormone levels, which is not consistent with the patient's low plasma TSH and hypothyroidism symptoms. Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary (Option B): In pituitary hypothyroidism, TSH would be low due to the lack of pituitary secretion. However, unlike the hypothalamic case, TSH would not increase after TRH administration because the pituitary is unable to respond to TRH. Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus (Option D): In hypothalamic hyperthyroidism, there would be a lack of feedback inhibition on the hypothalamus and pituitary, leading to elevated TSH and thyroid hormones. This is not consistent with the patient's low TSH and hypothyroidism. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page 2933

questions.question: Which of the following is seen in pituitary apoplexy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Shock Explanation: Shock is seen in pituitary apoplexy. Pituitary apoplexy Pathology Acute intra-pituitary hemorrhage resulting in an endocrine emergency It may arise spontaneously in preexisting adenomas, occur postpartum or be associated with conditions like diabetes, hypertension, sickle cell anemia, or acute shock. Severe ↓ ACTH and GH, other hormones may be ↓ or normal Clinical features Severe headache Central nervous system (CNS) hemorrhage Signs of meningeal irritation Loss of consciousness (secondary to adrenal insufficiency and shock) (Option C) Bilateral visual changes Ophthalmoplegia (eye muscle paralysis) Hypoglycemia Hypotension (Option A) Shock Cardiovascular collapse Management High-dose glucocorticoids are the first line of treatment to correct adrenal insufficiency, stabilize blood pressure, and correct hypoglycemia. Patients without evident visual loss or impaired consciousness can be managed conservatively with high-dose glucocorticoids. Urgent surgical decompression: Required for patients with significant or progressive visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or loss of consciousness. Monitoring: Visual recovery is inversely correlated with the duration of time after the acute event, so timely intervention is crucial. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2897,2898

questions.question: What is a macrovascular complication that develops in the advanced stages of diabetes?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Coronary artery disease Explanation: The macrovascular complication that develops in the advanced stages of diabetes is coronary artery disease. Macrovascular Complications of Diabetes Mellitus Major causes of morbidity and mortality in type 1 and type 2 diabetes. Involves large blood vessels, leading to: Coronary circulation: Myocardial ischaemia/infarction. Cerebral circulation: Transient ischaemic attack, stroke. Peripheral circulation: Claudication, ischaemia. Key Points: Excess mortality : Mainly due to myocardial infarction and stroke. Accelerated atherosclerosis : Earlier onset and more severe in diabetics. Amplified risk factors : Smoking, hypertension, dyslipidemia. Metabolic syndrome : Common in type 2 diabetes, with additional cardiovascular risk factors due to insulin resistance. Criteria for metabolic syndrome are Hypertension High Fasting glucose Elevated TG Low HDL Central obesity Statistics: Condition Increased Rate in Diabetics Cardiovascular death 1.7 times higher Myocardial infarction 1.8 times greater Stroke hospitalisation 1.5 times higher Non-traumatic amputations 60% occur in diabetics First cardiovascular event (type 1) 3 times higher in women, 2.3 times higher in men Mechanisms linking hyperglycemia to macrovascular disease: Increased vascular permeability : Due to high blood glucose. Lipoprotein deposition : Hyperinsulinemia and hypertension increase atherogenic lipoprotein deposits in large vessels. Risk Management: Glycaemic control : Reduces both microvascular and macrovascular complications. Blood pressure control : ACE inhibitors/ARBs are protective. Dyslipidemia management : Statins are recommended to lower cardiovascular risks. Lifestyle modifications : Smoking cessation, weight management, and regular physical activity are crucial. Diabetic Microvascular Complications Diabetic microangiopathy affects small blood vessels in diabetes, leading to significant morbidity and mortality. Key clinical syndromes include: Diabetic retinopathy (Option D) Diabetic nephropathy (Option C) Diabetic neuropathy Foot ulcer (Option B) is a microvascular complication of diabetes. Reference: Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 743, 755, 756, 757

questions.question: What is the disease depicted in the image below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cushing’s syndrome Explanation: The clinical manifestations in the image is of Cushing’s syndrome which is caused due to prolonged exposure to high levels of glucocorticoids. Cushing's syndrome Cushing's syndrome is a collection of symptoms resulting from prolonged exposure to high levels of glucocorticoids . Cushing's disease specifically refers to Cushing's syndrome caused by a pituitary corticotrope adenoma. It is relatively rare, but mild cases may be more common, particularly among those with symptoms like central obesity, type 2 diabetes and osteoporosis. Clinical Features of Cushing syndrome Physical: Weight gain and central obesity: Particularly around the face ("moon facies") and the back of the neck ("buffalo hump"). Skin changes: Thin and fragile skin prone to bruising, broad purple stretch marks, acne, and hirsutism. Musculoskeletal Issues: Osteoporosis (leading to fractures, especially in the spine) (Option B), muscle weakness, proximal myopathy (difficulty climbing stairs or rising from a chair), and decreased deep tendon reflexes. Metabolic: Glucose intolerance or diabetes and dyslipidemia (abnormal blood lipid levels). Cardiovascular: Hypertension, hypokalemia, and oedema. Reproductive: Decreased libido, and amenorrhea in women due to suppressed gonadotropin release. Psychological: Irritability, emotional instability, depression, cognitive impairment, and in severe cases, psychosis. Other features: Increased susceptibility to infections, elevated white blood cell count, eosinopenia Hypercoagulable state, increasing the risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presents with sudden onset of a headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating. He had several such episodes in the past. During these episodes, his BP is found to be high. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely aetiology?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Pheochromocytoma Explanation: The elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine with the given clinical features suggests phaeochromocytoma . Pheochromocytoma Description Pheochromocytomas are rare tumours arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla. The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines. Epidemiology Estimated to occur in 2 to 8 of 1 million persons per year. The mean age at diagnosis is 40 years, although the tumours can occur from early childhood until late in life. The classic ‘rule of tens’ is 10% bilateral, 10% extra-adrenal (Paragangliomas), and 10% metastatic. It is not used nowadays. Etiopathogenesis These tumors can be benign or malignant and are frequently associated with familial syndromes like Neurofibromatosis type 1, multiple endocrine neoplasia type II, and Von-Hippel Lindau disease. Catecholamines are produced in the chromaffin cells starting with the rate-limiting step of tyrosine hydroxylase (TH), regulating the conversion of tyrosine to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA). Pheochromocytomas release these catecholamines in various patterns ranging from paroxysmal, continuous, and mixed patterns. Norepinephrine is released continuously and can result in persistent hypertension, while epinephrine is released in a paroxysmal pattern resulting in tachyarrhythmias. Ryanodine-2 receptors (RyR2). Beta-2 adrenoceptors Alpha(1)-adrenoreceptors Histopathology Histology of the lesion characteristically shows zellballen nests of chromaffin cells with strong positivity to chromogranin, synaptophysin, CD56, and focally to S100. The presence of chromaffin cells in the extra-adrenal tissue is the only pathognomonic characteristic of the malignant form of the entity. Clinical features Classical triad Episode of palpitation Headache Profuse sweating The dominant sign is Hypertension Tachycardia Anxiety Subcutaneous neurofibromas Cafe-au-lait macules Thyroid mass Axillary freckling Lisch nodules on the iris Retinal angiomas Abdominal mass Diagnosis Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines. 24-hour urine test Catecholamines Fractionated metanephrines Total metanephrines Imaging : CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumour. 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease. MIBG scintigraphy Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning Differential Diagnosis Hyperthyroidism Renal artery stenosis Hyperaldosteronism Cardiomyopathy Postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS) Treatment The definitive treatment of pheochromocytoma is surgical resection. Preoperative preparation of the patient has to be considered, and blood pressure should be consistently < 160/90 mm Hg. Blood pressure is controlled by alpha-adrenergic blockers(phenoxybenzamine 0.5-4 mg/kg of body weight) Oral Prazosin or IV phentolamine can be used to control paroxysm. Unilateral Pheochromocytoma: Minimally invasive adrenalectomy: Preferred treatment for most unilateral adrenal pheochromocytomas. Open adrenalectomy Bilateral pheochromocytomas: Bilateral total adrenalectomy is associated with a lifelong need for steroid replacement with long-term side effects.

questions.question: What is the preferred medication for treating Hyperthyroidism during the second trimester of pregnancy?
questions.explanation: trimester of pregnancy. Incorrect options: Option A. Propyl Thiouracil is the drug of choice in Hyperthyroidism seen in the first trimester. Option C. Sodium iodide is highly contraindicated because it can completely cross the placenta. Option D . Pregnant women should avoid radioactive iodine as it can potentially cause miscarriage. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21e

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the thyroid function test results for a middle-aged woman diagnosed with Grave's disease, presenting symptoms such as tremors, palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities?

options.D: Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal

questions.explanation: autoimmune disorder causing overactivity of the thyroid gland, the production and release of thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) are increased. The elevated levels of thyroid hormones exert negative feedback on the pituitary gland, suppressing the secretion of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). Therefore, in Grave's disease, TSH levels are typically low. Incorrect Options: Option B- Low free T4 levels: In Grave's disease, there is excessive production of thyroid hormones, resulting in elevated levels of free T4. Therefore, low free T4 levels would be an unlikely finding in this condition. Option C- Low serum T3 levels: Grave's disease is characterized by increased production of both T3 and T4. Thus, low serum T3 levels would not be expected in this condition. Option D- Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal: In Grave's disease, the thyroid gland is hyperactive and takes up iodine more than usual. This results in an increased radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) on a nuclear medicine scan, not a below-normal uptake. Reference: .

questions.question: Fulminant diabetes mellitus is seen in?
questions.explanation: and complications. Coxsackie B virus, a type of enterovirus, has been associated with the development of fulminant diabetes mellitus. The virus can cause damage to the pancreatic beta cells, leading to a sudden and complete loss of insulin production. Incorrect options: Options A: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) : While DKA is a serious complication of diabetes characterized by high blood sugar, ketone production, and metabolic acidosis, it is not specifically associated with a rapid and severe onset like fulminant diabetes. Options C: Non-ketotic hyperosmolar coma: Non-ketotic hyperosmolar coma is a life-threatening complication of diabetes characterized by extremely high blood sugar and severe dehydration. It is not typically associated with a rapid and sudden onset like fulminant diabetes. Options D: Autoimmune pancreatitis: Autoimmune pancreatitis is a rare form of chronic pancreatitis caused by an autoimmune reaction. It is not typically associated with a rapid and severe onset of diabetes. Reference: .

questions.question: A 25-year-old male patient came with complaints of palpitations, sweating, and restlessness. He has a complaint of sweaty palms. Clinical findings are depicted in the image given below. What is the diagnostic finding seen in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Thyroid receptor antibody This patient's clinical presentation suggests Graves' disease, a form of hyperthyroidism. The symptoms, including palpitations, sweating, restlessness, and sweaty palms, are common in hyperthyroid states. The diagnostic finding in Graves' disease is elevated thyroid receptor antibodies. These antibodies, specifically thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI), stimulate the thyroid gland, leading to excess production of thyroid hormones, resulting in hyperthyroid symptoms. Graves' Disease is an autoimmune disorder causing hyperthyroidism due to thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) that stimulate the thyroid gland, increasing hormone production (T3 and T4). Clinical Features: Hyperthyroid symptoms: Palpitations, sweating, restlessness, weight loss, heat intolerance, tachycardia, hyperactivity, irritability. Graves' ophthalmopathy: Exophthalmos, lid retraction, lid lag, conjunctival injection, dry eyes, visual disturbances. Diagnosis: Elevated TSI and thyroid function tests showing elevated T3/T4 and suppressed TSH. Radioactive iodine uptake: Increased in Graves' disease. Management: Antithyroid drugs: Propylthiouracil (PTU) or methimazole to inhibit thyroid hormone production. Radioactive iodine (RAI): Ablates overactive thyroid tissue but does not treat ophthalmopathy. Surgical treatment: Thyroidectomy if needed for large goiters or refractory cases. Graves' ophthalmopathy: Managed with corticosteroids, radiotherapy, or orbital decompression surgery for severe cases. Signs in Grave’s ophthalmopathy Signs in Grave’s ophthalmopathy Dalrymple’s sign It is due to the contraction of Muller’s muscles Upper lid retraction M/C presenting sign Von Graefe’s sign/ Lid-lag/ Stare sign It is the inability to close the upper eyelid It is the earliest sign There is inadequate blinking leading to exposure keratitis Lid lag of the upper eyelid on downward gaze Enroth’s sign It is the fullness/ edema of the lower eyelids Gifford’s sign _ Difficulty in eversion of the upper eyelid Mobius sign _ Convergence weakness Griffith sign Lower lid lag on upward gaze Stellwag’s sign _ Incomplete and infrequent blinking Joffroy’s sign _ Lack of

questions.question: A female patient with type 1 DM and hypothyroidism presented with chronic oral mucocutaneous candidiasis for 5 years. She is diagnosed with autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) DM type-1 association is high Explanation: Type 1 diabetes mellitus (DM) is commonly associated with APS Type 2, it is less frequently seen in APS Type 1. Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy Syndrome (APS) Type 1 is also known as APECED (Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy, Candidiasis, and Ectodermal Dystrophy). APS Type 1 is more associated with conditions like hypoparathyroidism, adrenal insufficiency, and chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis. Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy Syndrome (APS) Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy Syndrome iis a group of autoimmune disorders characterized by the immune system mistakenly attacking multiple endocrine glands, leading to hormonal imbalances. It is classified into two main types Feature APS Type 1 (APECED) APS Type 2 (Schmidt Syndrome) Genetic Cause Mutation in AIRE gene (Autoimmune Regulator) Associated with HLA-DR3 and HLA-DR4 alleles Inheritance Pattern Autosomal recessive Polygenic, complex inheritance Age of Onset Childhood onset (Option B ruled out) Adulthood onset (20-40 years) Clinical Features Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis , hypoparathyroidism , addison’s disease (Options C & D ruled out) Addison’s disease, autoimmune thyroid disease, type 1 diabetes mellitus Other Associated Conditions Hypogonadism, alopecia, pernicious anemia, autoimmune enteropathy, keratoconjunctivitis Vitiligo, myasthenia gravis, pernicious anemia, celiac disease Endocrine Glands Affected Parathyroid, adrenal, gonads, pancreatic islets, thyroid Adrenal, thyroid, pancreatic islets Diagnosis Genetic testing for AIRE mutation, endocrine function tests Endocrine function tests, autoantibody screening Management Hormone replacement (calcium & vitamin D for hypoparathyroidism, hydrocortisone for Addison’s), antifungal treatment for candidiasis Hormone replacement (thyroxine for hypothyroidism, insulin for diabetes, corticosteroids for adrenal insufficiency) Prognosis Progressive, can be life-threatening without early treatment Chronic but manageable with lifelong hormone therapy APECED : Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy-Candidiasis-Ectodermal Dystrophy Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 1123.

questions.question: A patient with a history of Wilson's disease presents with neurological manifestations. Which of the following is the best diagnostic modality?
questions.explanation: disorder characterized by excessive accumulation of copper in various body tissues, primarily the liver and brain. The best diagnostic modality to confirm Wilson's disease, especially in the presence of neurological manifestations, is hepatic parenchymal demonstration of copper . This is usually done by performing a liver biopsy to measure the hepatic copper concentration, which is considered the gold standard for diagnosis. Incorrect Options: Option A - Serum ceruloplasmin: While serum ceruloplasmin is often low in Wilson's disease, it is not the most reliable diagnostic tool, as ceruloplasmin levels can be low in other conditions and may be normal in some patients with Wilson's disease. Option B - Urinary copper excretion: This test measures 24-hour urinary copper excretion and is elevated in Wilson's disease, but it is not as definitive as hepatic copper measurement. It is useful as part of the diagnostic workup but not the best single test. Option D - Anti-tissue transglutaminase (Anti-tTG) antibody: This antibody is associated with celiac disease and is not relevant to the diagnosis of Wilson's disease.

questions.question: Patient present with large sweaty hands, macroglossia and frontal bossing. Select the best test for confirmation of the diagnosis:
questions.explanation: acromegaly (often caused by excess growth hormone) is GH suppression test. 75g of oral glucose is administered and blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, and 120 minutes. Normally, glucose suppressess GH, If GH > 1ng/ml, it is confirmatory of acromegaly. Incorrect Options: Option A - GHRH levels: Growth Hormone-Releasing Hormone (GHRH) levels are not typically used for the diagnosis of acromegaly. While GHRH can stimulate growth hormone release, its levels are not directly indicative of acromegaly. Option C - IGF-2: IGF-2 is not typically used for diagnosing acromegaly. It is more relevant in conditions like certain tumors and is not a primary diagnostic marker for acromegaly. Option B - Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF-1) . IGF-1 levels are elevated in acromegaly due to the increased secretion of growth hormone. IGF-1 is a stable marker that reflects chronic exposure to growth hormone and is therefore used as the screening test for acromegaly.

questions.question: In a patient with type 1 diabetes at the 3rd stage of beta cell damage, which of the following conditions is most likely to be observed?
questions.explanation: significant beta cell damage due to an ongoing autoimmune process, leading to dysglycemia (impaired glucose levels). At this stage, there is insufficient insulin production to maintain normal glucose levels, causing hyperglycemia, which characterizes dysglycemia. Incorrect Options: Option A - Autoimmune positive + normoglycemia: This situation is typically seen in the early stages of type 1 diabetes (Stage 1), where there is an autoimmune response against beta cells, but blood glucose levels remain normal because there is still enough insulin production to maintain glucose homeostasis. Option B - Autoimmune negative + normoglycemia: This scenario is not associated with type 1 diabetes. In type 1 diabetes, the autoimmune process is the hallmark feature. If there are no autoimmune markers (autoantibodies), it suggests that type 1 diabetes is unlikely. Normoglycemia in such a context would also not indicate any beta cell damage typical of type 1 diabetes. Option D - Autoimmune negative + dysglycemia: This condition is more suggestive of type 2 diabetes or other forms of diabetes where autoimmune destruction of beta cells is not present. Dysglycemia without autoimmunity does not fit with the progression of type 1 diabetes, which is defined by the presence of autoimmune markers.

questions.question: A patient presents with features of hyperthyroidism, characterized by decreased TSH levels and elevated free T3 and T4. Which of the following statements about this condition is NOT true?

options.A: The condition will improve simultaneously with improvement in the thyrotoxic state.
options.B: In 10% of cases, the condition is present without hyperthyroidism.
options.C: Severe disease can cause vision loss.
options.D: No specs criteria is used for this condition.

questions.explanation: state. state: This statement is not true because the condition being referred to is likely Graves' ophthalmopathy (thyroid eye disease), which does not always improve simultaneously with the resolution of the thyrotoxic state. The eye manifestations can persist or even worsen independently of the thyroid hormone levels. Incorrect Options: Options B, C and D are true statements regarding hyperthyroidism and Graves' ophthalmopathy.

questions.question: A young woman presents with weight loss, tachycardia, heat intolerance, and tremors. On examination, she has exophthalmos. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: hyperthyroidism. Symptoms such as weight loss, tachycardia, heat intolerance, and tremors are all characteristic of an overactive thyroid. Exophthalmos (protrusion of the eyes) is a hallmark feature of Graves' disease, distinguishing it from other thyroid conditions. This makes Graves' disease the most likely diagnosis given the patient's symptoms and findings. Incorrect Options: Option A - Parkinson's disease: Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by tremors, bradykinesia (slowness of movement), rigidity, and postural instability. It does not typically present with weight loss, heat intolerance, or exophthalmos, which are more suggestive of a hyperthyroid state. Option C - Addison's disease: Addison's disease is a disorder of adrenal insufficiency characterized by symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, hyperpigmentation, hypotension, and salt cravings. It does not typically present with tachycardia, heat intolerance, tremors, or exophthalmos, which are indicative of hyperthyroidism rather than adrenal insufficiency. Option D - Alzheimer's disease: Alzheimer's disease is a neurodegenerative condition that primarily affects memory and cognitive function. It does not cause weight loss, tachycardia, heat intolerance, tremors, or exophthalmos, which are not associated with its clinical presentation.

questions.question: In Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus, what characterizes stage 3 of beta-cell destruction?
questions.explanation: of beta-cell destruction typically occurs in stages: Stage 1: Autoimmune destruction of beta cells, but no symptoms are present. Normal blood glucose levels. Stage 2: Progressive beta-cell destruction with dysglycemia (impaired glucose metabolism) but no symptoms of hyperglycemia yet. Stage 3: Significant beta-cell destruction leading to symptomatic hyperglycemia. Patients will present with symptoms such as polyuria, polydipsia, and weight loss due to elevated blood glucose levels. At Stage 3, the destruction is advanced enough that insulin production is insufficient to maintain normal glucose levels, resulting in symptomatic hyperglycemia. Incorrect Options: Option B - Dysglycemic symptomatic: Dysglycemia refers to abnormal glucose levels, which could be either high (hyperglycemia) or low (hypoglycemia). In Type 1 DM, Stage 3 is characterized specifically by symptomatic hyperglycemia, not just dysglycemia. Option C - Normoglycemic symptomatic: Normoglycemic means normal blood glucose levels. In Stage 3 of Type 1 DM, the patient is not normoglycemic; instead, they are experiencing symptomatic hyperglycemia due to the loss of beta-cell function. Option D - Dysglycemic asymptomatic: Dysglycemia asymptomatic implies abnormal glucose levels without symptoms. In Stage 3 of Type 1 DM, patients are symptomatic due to hyperglycemia, so this option does not fit the stage described. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following antidiabetic drugs can cause glucosuria?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Empagliflozin Explanation: Empagliflozin belongs to the class of SGLT-2 inhibitors that work by blocking sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 in the proximal convoluted tubules of the nephron. This mechanism prevents the reabsorption of glucose and sodium back into the bloodstream, leading to glucosuria. The drug provides multiple benefits including reduced progression of chronic kidney disease, diuretic effects through sodium loss, and blood pressure reduction of 3-6 mmHg. However, these drugs are contraindicated in patients with eGFR <45 ml/min due to reduced efficacy and risk of urinary tract infections. Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) Inhibitors Examples Canagliflozin Dapagliflozin Empagliflozin Mechanism of Action Blocks reabsorption of glucose in the proximal convoluted tubule, promoting the excretion of sodium and glucose in urine Indications Reduce progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD) Diuretic effect, leading to sodium loss Reduces systolic blood pressure (SBP) by 3-6 mmHg Cardiorenal advantage CHF to decrease mortality with or without DM Side Effects Increased risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs) Glucosuria (leading to UTIs and vulvovaginal candidiasis) Dehydration (orthostatic hypotension) Weight loss Contraindications Not recommended if estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) < 45 ml/min Use with caution in renal insufficiency (decreased efficacy with decreased GFR) Glimepiride (Option A) : This sulfonylurea medication works by stimulating insulin release from pancreatic beta cells, causing hypoglycemia and weight gain. It does not cause glucosuria as its mechanism of action is focused on increasing insulin secretion. Exenatide (Option B): This GLP-1 receptor agonist binds to GLP-1 receptor in pancreatic beta-cells in turn increasing insulin secretion and suppressing glucagon secretion. Its actions include delayed gastric emptying, induces early satiety (weight loss) & stabilizes atherosclerotic plaque (reduction in cardiovascular mortality). Its mechanism does not involve renal glucose reabsorption thus does not cause glucosuria. Acarbose (Option C) : This alpha-glucosidase inhibitor works by controlling post-prandial glucose spikes through reduced carbohydrate absorption in the intestine. It may cause abdominal bloating and diarrhea but does not affect renal glucose handling or cause glucosuria. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 3110- 3113

questions.question: A diabetic patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of fatigue and frequent urination. On examination vitals are stable and an HbA1c is done. What is the cut-off percentage used for determining controlled diabetes?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 7.0 Explanation: According to the American College of Physicians, the target HbA1c for determining controlled diabetes is <7.0% for adults with diabetes. This value represents optimal glycemic control, though it may be adjusted to <8.0% in elderly frail patients . Glycated Hemoglobin (HbA1c) effectively assesses overall glycemic control and is suitable for diagnosing diabetes in asymptomatic individuals. HbA1c prediction in undiagnosed individuals: < 5.7% : Normal 5.7% - 6.5% : Pre-diabetic > 6.5% : Diabetic For patients with existing diabetes, HbA1c is used to evaluate the degree of effective control on diabetes. The cutoffs recommended by ACP for monitoring effective control include: HbA1c < 7.0% Preprandial capillary plasma glucose between 80-130 mg/dL Postprandial capillary plasma glucose <180 mg/dL. 6.0 (Option A) , 6.5 (Option B) & 7.5 (Option D) are incorrect values according to ACP recommendation. Reference: https://www.acpjournals.org/doi/10.7326/M17-0939

questions.question: Which of the following is associated with MEN-1 syndrome?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Parathyroid adenoma Explanation: MEN-1 syndrome, also known as Wermer syndrome , results from a mutation in the MEN-1 gene located on chromosome 11q13 . This gene mutation leads to uncontrolled mitosis in endocrine glands. The classic triad of MEN-1 includes parathyroid adenoma (the most common manifestation), pancreatic adenoma, and pituitary adenoma . Parathyroid involvement is typically the first and most frequent manifestation of this syndrome. Types of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia MEN Type I MEN Type II MEN Type III MEN Type IV Cause Defect of chromosome 11q13 causing MEN 1 gene mutation Also called Wermer’s syndrome Defect of chr.10 leading to mutation of RET gene Also called Sipple’s syndrome Also called MEN II B , it is a variant of Type 2 MEN Defect of chr.12 causing CDKN1B gene Tumors Included Parathyroid adenoma (most common) It presents with primary hyperparathyroidism ( ↑ PTH and ↑ Ca) All the 4 glands can be included. Rx: Total/subtotal parathyroid resection Parathyroid adenoma ( most common, and calcium can be normal) Medullary carcinoma thyroid ( most common) Parathyroid adenoma ( Presents as hypercalcemia) Pancreatic adenoma Presents as Gastrinoma or Zollinger-Ellison syndrome This leads to peptic ulcer disease in the duodenum, which is the leading cause of death in this type. Pheochromocytoma . Pheochromocytoma (Most important criterion for both MEN 2 and MEN 3): Presents with elevated blood pressure. Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma Pituitary adenoma: Prolactinoma, causing amenorrhea and Infertility Medullary thyroid carcinoma Calcitonin is the tumor marker present Cold nodules are seen on the thyroid scan Metastasis can be traced with PET scan Visible neck mass, causing dysphagia Rx - Prophylactic thyroidectomy Reproductive tract tumors Testicular tumors Neuroendocrine tumor (Cervix) Associated conditions Angio I broma Collagenoma Adrenocortical tumor Carcinoid tumors/Argenta I noma Pheochromocytoma (only in 1%) Congenital aganglionosis, Hirschsprung disease Marfanoid habitus Medullated corneal nerve I bers Mucosal neuromas Megacolon and Multiple diverticulae Occasionally with Renal tumor Adrenal tumor Parotid tumor (Option B) : Parotid tumors are not part of the multiple endocrine neoplasia syndromes. These tumors affect the salivary glands and are not associated with endocrine disorders. Renal cell carcinoma (Option C) : While some renal manifestations may occur in MEN syndromes (such as in MEN IV), renal cell carcinoma is not a feature of MEN-1. It may be coincidentally present but is not a defining feature of the syndrome. Pheochromocytoma (Option D) : Pheochromocytoma is actually associated with MEN-II/Sipple syndrome & MEN-III, not MEN-1. Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2983 - 2990 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 868, 869

questions.question: All of the below are features of Conn's syndrome except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Metabolic acidosis Explanation: Metabolic acidosis is not a feature of Conn's syndrome. Conn's syndrome, also known as primary hyperaldosteronism , is characterized by autonomous aldosterone production from the adrenal glands. The condition leads to increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the distal tubules. It is characterized by Hypertension, Hypokalemia and Metabolic Alkalosis (leading to muscle cramps). The pathophysiology involves excess aldosterone stimulating the ENaC channel , resulting in increased sodium and water reabsorption while promoting urinary loss of potassium and hydrogen ions. Conn Syndrome / Primary Hyperaldosteronism Definition Primary hyperaldosteronism characterized by excessive aldosterone secretion from adrenal glands with suppressed plasma renin Epidemiology Most common cause of secondary hypertension (6-20% of adult hypertensive patients) Higher prevalence in resistant hypertension (up to 30%) 2x more common in women Etiology Aldosterone-producing adenoma (50-60%) Bilateral idiopathic adrenal hyperplasia Aldosterone-producing adrenal carcinoma (1%) Familial hyperaldosteronism (Types 1-3) Pathophysiology ↑ Aldosterone → ↑ Na+ reabsorption → plasma volume expansion ↑ K+ excretion → hypokalemia Can lead to tissue inflammation and fibrosis in heart, kidneys, vasculature Clinical Features Resistant hypertension Muscle weakness/cramping Fatigue Headaches Polydipsia/polyuria NO edema (due to spontaneous natriuresis) Lab Findings ↓ K+ (can be normal in up to 38%) ↑ Na+ Metabolic alkalosis ↑ Urinary K+ excretion (>30 mmol/day) Suppressed plasma renin ↑ Aldosterone-to-renin ratio (ARR) Diagnostic Criteria Initial screening: ARR >40 Confirmatory tests: Salt loading test Fludrocortisone suppression test Captopril suppression test Imaging: CT scan for adenoma Adrenal venous sampling for lateralization Treatment Adenoma: Laparoscopic adrenalectomy Bilateral hyperplasia: Medical management Medical options: Spironolactone (first-line) Eplerenone Amiloride Prognosis Surgery: 30-60% cure rate for adenomas High morbidity/mortality if untreated May need long-term BP monitoring High-Yield Associations Normal K+ doesn't exclude diagnosis No edema despite hyperaldosteronism Screen all resistant hypertension cases Metabolic alkalosis (Option A) is a characteristic feature of Conn's syndrome.
